project.teaser: Global terrestrial plant biodiversity remains a largely untapped source of natural bioactive compounds. In fact, valid sources are even “hiding in plain sight”, yet not “within reach” due to lack of effective technical solutions to unlock their potential. In this...
project.objective: Global terrestrial plant biodiversity remains a largely untapped source of natural bioactive compounds. In fact, valid sources are even “hiding in plain sight”, yet not “within reach” due to lack of effective technical solutions to unlock their potential. In this context, the PROSPLIGN consortium has developed an innovative bioprospecting approach that uses cutting-edge and complementary chemical and enzymatic methods, supported by statistical analysis and coupled with high-throughput detection methods, to enable the discovery of bioactive molecules from lignin, one of the fractions of the most abundant biopolymer on Earth (lignocellulose). Lignin “chemical biodiversity” will enable PROSPLIGN to cover three target markets (pharmaceuticals, cosmetics and fragrances) with a combined market of >€1.4 trillion. The project will use lignin derived from 9 different species and investigate at least 3 different chemical approaches and 10 different enzymes to obtain up to 1000 mixtures of lignin-derived compounds, and then pass a progressively narrower “hit validation funnel” in industrially relevant environments, being screened via up to 17 different bioactivity assays. Sustainable production routes for at least 2 of the most promising compounds per sector, directly or following derivatisation, will be proposed. Compared to traditional approaches, PROSPLIGN's bioprospecting avoids animal cruelty, expensive exploration efforts (no novel animal/plants discovery), disruptive extractions (seeking “hidden gems” in an abundant but underexploited “biomass mine”), and directly targets the liberation of readily testable bio/chemical-functionality present in plant material, superior to other approaches relying on “manipulation-intensive” microbial strain culture or “extrapolation” from DNA/RNA). Ultimately, PROSPLIGN will contribute to a new generation of biobased bioactives, unlocking more value from existing sources whose immense potential has yet to be harnessed.
project.title: Prospecting natural lignin biodiversity towards unlocking value-added bioactive motifs and molecules
project.keywords: bioprospecting, lignin, natural biodiversity, depolymerisation, lignans

result.title: Summary Report on Sourcing and characterisation of biomass for lignin bioprospecting
result.description: Summary report giving an overview of our lignin sourcing strategies, quality assessment processes, and key strategic considerations from Tasks T2.2 and T2.3. Offers insights into lignin sourcing feasibility and sustainability. Details of assessment of sourced lignin quality, including data on β-O-4 content, molecular weight, purity, solubility profiles, and insights to bioactivity potential.

result.title: Mid project DCE plan and report
result.description: Mid project revised DCE action plan from T7.1 with a section of latest DCE activities in T7.2

result.title: Periodic Reporting for period 1 - PROSPLIGN (Prospecting natural lignin biodiversity towards unlocking value-added bioactive motifs and molecules)
result.teaser: The global community is facing a critical need for new, sustainable, and natural ingredients for various high-value sectors, including pharmaceuticals, cosmetics, and fragrances. While terrestrial plant biodiversity represents a vast, untapped source of bioactive compounds...

category.title: Report Summary
category.description: Result: Publishable summary (FP7 SESAM) and Summary for publication (H2020 SyGMa)

result.title: Intermediate policy brief
result.description: 2-3 page document including policy recommendations relevant for the topics of the project

result.title: Preliminary summary report on isolation and purification of bioactive compounds
result.description: Preliminary summary report on activities performed in T4.4 involving isolation and purification of bioactive compounds. This summary provides an overview of the key preliminary findings and outcomes related to the isolation, purification, and characterisation of bioactive compounds derived from depolymerised lignin mixtures. It highlights the scalable processes employed for extracting and purifying compounds. Includes insights into the analytical methods used for characterisation and the significance of the results. Offers a general understanding of the project's progress in identifying promising candidates with industrial relevance.

result.title: Preliminary DCE Plan
result.description: First “hitting the ground running” report regarding T7.1 baseline DCE strategies and tools

result.title: Project Management Guidelines
result.description: Report related to T1.1, 1.2, 1.3, and 1.4 outlining consortium structure, Grant Agreement compliance, financial reporting, EC deliverable standards, internal communication plan, and quality assurance procedure.

result.title: Preliminary Data Management Plan (DMP)
result.description: Preliminary DMP focused on the FAIR approach – output of T1.5

result.title: Preliminary summary report bioassays of depolymerized lignin mixtures
result.description: Preliminary summary report on WP4 activities on screening of depolymerized lignin mixtures in bioassays relevant to pharmaceutical, cosmetics and fragrances sector. The report highlights the comprehensive screening efforts carried out in T4.1, T4.2, and T4.3, which aim to identify bioactive compounds with applications in the pharmaceuticals, cosmetics and fragrance industries. While maintaining confidentiality regarding specific compound details, this summary offers insights into the screening methodologies, objectives, and the significance of the findings for each sector.

result.title: Preliminary summary report on Lignin chemical and enzymatic depolymerization
result.description: Preliminary summary report on WP3 activities leading to optimised methods for the T3.4 chemical and T3.3 enzymatic depolymerization of lignin. Insights into the methods, optimizations, and initial findings regarding the cleavage of lignin's intricate structures are reported.

category.title: pharmaceutical drugs
category.displayCode: /medical and health sciences/basic medicine/pharmacology and pharmacy/pharmaceutical drugs

category.title: Digital agenda
category.description: This tracker monitors Horizon Europe’s financial contribution to the development of digital technologies and the digitisation of the economy and society (known as ‘Digital transition’).

category.title: Clean air
category.description: This tracker monitors the Horizon Europe’s financial contribution to the clean air policy (National Emission Ceiling Directive) aiming to improve ambient air quality and tackle air pollution, to protect the environment and human health.

category.title: Artificial intelligence
category.description: This tracker monitors Horizon Europe’s financial contribution to the development and deployment of AI-based technologies and solutions. Projects that develop AI-tools as part of their research method are included

category.title: Climate action
category.description: This tracker monitors the Horizon Europe’s financial contribution to both mitigating climate change (e.g., contributions to the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions) and adapting to climate change by building resilience (e.g., regarding floods, droughts, spatial planning and better governance, adaptation to changing climate in value chains, etc.).

category.title: Biodiversity
category.description: This tracker monitors the Horizon Europe’s financial contribution to Europe’s biodiversity’s path to recovery including species protection, ecosystem conservation, and habitat rehabilitation, all essential for resilience in climate adaptation and addressing ecosystem services but also environmental crime and the health-environment connection.
